## PR Summary

Ubuntu18.04 seems to default to `C.UTF-8` for LANG (representing InvariantCulture) which results in a case-sensitive hashtable since CurrentCultureIgnoreCase doesn't work for that culture.  Fix is to use OrdinalIgnoreCase instead.

body:
In reading many issue's in this repo I see a smallish but nevertheless a common theme occurring.

- Badly written issues, mainly in content of the issue but often also in the technical context behind the issue that can mislead the readers into what the actual issue is
- Issues that due to being written up badly, perhaps ENG is not the writers first language so translations get lost in the midst, this can lead to long time being spent on issues and PR's intended to fix what could be completely incorrectly understood issue.

To combat this, I am suggesting

- [ ] That the Issue Template for Bug gets updated to include a message that suggests for Triage purposes that the reporter should try to include a screen capture of the issue as it's happening. This would be extremely useful for issues where this could hypothetically reduce the time taken to come to a correct diagnosis of the issue, and further confirmation that the issue is in fact correctly raised and contains the right level of detail to aid in lowering the mean time between confirmed diagnosis with potential fix identified and then the time to implement said fix.
- [ ] That other Issue Templates be updated accordingly to suggest that the above would be a beneficial addition where possible.
- [ ] If implemented then new labels should also be added to signify a screen capture was/was not included in the issue submission

I think that the above will help with longer term metrics to see how well the current triaging system works (which seems to be pretty solid thus far in the majority of cases) and if there may be any potential areas to improve further.

title: PowerShell Core doesn't display text

body:
On macOS, both Terminal.app and iTerm2.app support keyboard shortcut <kbd>Command-K</kbd> for clearing the screen as well as the scrollback buffer.

PowerShell doesn't realize that the cursor position has been reset, and prints user input on the previously active line instead of the first.


# Steps to reproduce

On macOS:

```powershell
Get-ChildItem -Recurse | Select -First 100 # issue command that places cursor on the bottom line
# Press Command-K
```

# Expected behavior

The prompt should be displayed on the 1st line, and typing input should show next to it.

# Actual behavior

While the prompt is displayed on the 1st line, typing input causes it to be printed on the line that was active when the keyboard shortcut was pressed; note how the `a`, typed after clearing the screen, is printed on the bottom line:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/588825/50517254-cd370380-0aaf-11e9-8f28-4475e9459af2.png)

# Environment data


```none
PowerShell Core v6.2.0-preview.3 (6.2.0-preview.3) on macOS 10.14.2
```

body:
## PR Summary

`Clear-Host` currently uses the `clear` command to clear the screen.  However, that merely clears what is on the visible screen and not the entire buffer.  This is a difference in behavior with Windows which also clears the scrollback buffer.  Fix is to output the `ESC[3J` CSI sequence to clear the scrollback buffer.

cc @mklement0 

Fix https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/8554

body:
# Summary of the new feature/enhancement

As as user, I want the same 'clear' experience in PowerShell on *nix, as I have in Windows. Currently, if I use 'clear' in Windows, this clears the buffer. Currently, in *nix, it appears to create a gap of blank lines and leaves the buffer mostly intact; so, I can scroll up to see the history.

I _believe_ that this is because pwsh is leveraging terminal and when clear is input by the user, it is passed to the terminal. However, the behaviour one would expect should be the equivalent of 'tput reset' in the terminal window - as this would be the same experience seen in PowerShell in Windows.

# Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Instead of allowing 'clear' to pass to the terminal, translate the command to 'tput reset' and pass that to the terminal.

## PR Summary

The `help` function passes the returned content to a pager unless it is of type `HelpInfoShort` (used when multiple matches found).  This includes passing `AliasHelpInfo` which is short enough to not require passing to the pager.  Fix is to simply pass output to pipeline if the result type is `AliasHelpInfo` rather than through the pager.

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/8541

##### SUMMARY

I'm reposting this here based on comments my other ticket with ansible and powershell.  

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/48881
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/50352

Essentially pwsh is outputting a console escape character sequence \u001b[?1h\u001b=, which is causing issues.   Can this be disabled?   Also it appear that if you try to run powershell over ssh it just hangs.  Example.

```
ssh -o ServerAliveInterval=30 root@somemachine pwsh -noni -f /tmp/hang.ps1
```

if i run that command directly on the machine i have no issues
------------------------------------------

Original info


We have some powershell functionality that runs fine when directly used on a linux machine or running through ansible using localhost.  If using ssh it will break with 'shared conneciton to XXX closed'.   This appears to happen with 'script' or when using a custom library.  It works fine with 'shell'.   I've included a sample project to simplify

Steps to install powershell
```
curl https://packages.microsoft.com/config/rhel/7/prod.repo | tee /etc/yum.repos.d/microsoft.repo;
yum install -y powershell-6.0.2-1.rhel.7
ln /usr/bin/pwsh /usr/bin/powershell
```

Is support for powershell limited to localhost?

script module and custom library written in powershell

body:
# Summary of the new feature/enhancement

As a user I want to have an option to hide the file extensions for executables and executable scripts known to the system, when using the tab expansion feature of Powershell.
This would allow me to use them like I'm used to, because I do not care about the file extension.

# Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Hide the file extension when using tab expansion to expand commands located in $env:PATH that have extensions listed in the $env:PATHEXT.
This would make the behavior similar to how the search for executable scripts work.

Example 1:
* I have a script called `My-Function.ps1` in a folder in my $env:PATH
* I can run it by typing `My-Function` as the search inside the path includes .ps1 files
* When I type `My<tab>`, it expands to `My-Function.ps1`
* Instead `My<tab>` should expand to `My-Function` as the extension is redundant / not needed

Example 2:
* I type `powersh<tab>` and it expands to `powershell` and not `powershell.exe`

body:
## PR Summary

Using this [script](https://gist.github.com/SteveL-MSFT/f4e977caa3c44be2ce35f8012b151b4c) each folder is a separate commit making it easier to review.

The regular expression looks for any closing brace not followed by:

| catch, else, finally, another closing brace, newline, space, hash, slash (comment), * (comment)

In addition, because .NET RegEx doesn't support look behind, I skip any closing braces that are part of: { get; set; }

Some of the Copyright notices show changed because git resaved the file without BOM.

Manually reviewed all the changes.

Related https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/8500

body:
# Steps to reproduce
```PowerShell
function Export-Excel {
    [CmdletBinding(DefaultParameterSetName = 'Default')]
    Param(
        [Parameter(ParameterSetName = "Default")]
        [Parameter(ParameterSetName = "AutoFilter")]
        [String]$Path,

        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true, ParameterSetName = "PackageDefault")]
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true, ParameterSetName = "PackageAutoFilter")]
        $ExcelPackage,

        [Parameter(ValueFromPipeline = $true)]
        $TargetData,

        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true, ParameterSetName = 'AutoFilter')]
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true, ParameterSetName = 'PackageAutoFilter')]
        $AutoFilter,

        [Parameter(ParameterSetName = 'Default')]#, ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName)]
        [Parameter(ParameterSetName = 'PackageDefault')]#, ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName)]
        [String]$TableName,
        [Parameter(ParameterSetName = 'Default')]
        [Parameter(ParameterSetName = 'PackageDefault')]
        [Switch]$Table,
        [Parameter(ParameterSetName = 'Default')]
        [Parameter(ParameterSetName = 'PackageDefault')]
        $TableStyle = 'Medium6'
    )
    "ParameterSet: " + $PSCmdlet.ParameterSetName
}
# Works
Export-Excel -ExcelPackage 5 -TargetData 5
Export-Excel -ExcelPackage 5
# Prompt for "AutoFilter:"
5 | Export-Excel -ExcelPackage 5
```

# Expected behavior
```none
ParameterSet: PackageDefault
ParameterSet: PackageDefault
ParameterSet: PackageDefault
```

# Actual behavior
```none
ParameterSet: PackageDefault
ParameterSet: PackageDefault

cmdlet Export-Excel at command pipeline position 1
Supply values for the following parameters:
AutoFilter:
```

When not passing $ExcelPackage or passing it as a parameter ParameterSet PackageDefault is selected, but when providing it from Pipeline it asks for $AutoFilter from the wrong ParameterSet.

Tested on 5.1 and 6.2.0-preview.3

I also tried to workaround this by providing multiple DefaultParameterSetName hoping it will evaluate them in order but looks like it's not a thing, Feature request?
```PowerShell
[CmdletBinding(DefaultParameterSetName = 'Default,', 'PackageDefault')]
```
`Cannot find an overload for ".ctor" and the argument count: "1".`

body:
## PR Summary

Related #8120.

The PR is only demo how we could use Simple Case Folding to speed up PowerShell engine.

Current code uses 2-level translation table to fold Unicode strings. The table is compact: full table is 128 Kb, the compressed table is ~10Kb.

New string compare works in 3-4 faster than standard ignore case comparer.
With using the new comparer in only one place you can also see a marked improvement in startup time.
Perhaps we could use the comparer in other places.

I push alternative code too so you could experiment. Tools and temporary benchmarks is also pushed.

body:
On recent Windows versions, you can configure the Quick Link menu opened via <kbd>Windows</kbd>+<kbd>X</kbd> to open a PowerShell prompt instead of a Command Prompt. This option has always been powerful but slow. PowerShell Core's faster startup can help here, but only if the Quick Link menu item opens PowerShell Core instead of PowerShell.

When PowerShell Core is installed on Windows, there should be a way the user can configure which version of PowerShell to use from the Quick Link menu.

An alternative approach is to provide a way to remove the non-Core version of PowerShell so that there is no ambiguity. For users who only need the features in Core, this would be the most straightforward.

body:
## PR Summary

When installing (or upgrading) Preview builds the component ids for the files are the same as the installed files from the stable MSI.  MSI sees this and assumes the file is already installed so skips installing files that haven't changed (been updated) which results in missing files in the preview install folder and pwsh fails to start.  Fix is to dynamically generate new component ids (and compoentrefs) in `files.wxs` using `_Preview` suffix and use that when building a preview package.

Tested manually.

cc @bergmeister if you can help validate different scenarios.

Fix https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/8289

body:
It's just surprising to me that Powershell doesn't give a greater precedence to -and over -or, like in other languages like C# or vbscript.  I guess there's some technical reason for it.

<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

This repository is **ONLY** for PowerShell Core 6 issues.

- Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/known-issues-ps6?view=powershell-6).

-->

# Steps to reproduce

```powershell

```

# Expected behavior

```none
C:\> $true -or $true -and $false
True
```

# Actual behavior

```none
C:\> $true -or $true -and $false
False

C:\> $true -or ($true -and $false)
True
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.1.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.16299
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

body:
The comma operator has the highest precedence of any operator (excepting casts and enclosed statements like subexpressions and script blocks), causing (for example) `+` to behave as though concatenating arrays rather than adding values as one would more reasonably expect (in my opinion).

# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
$a = 0..10
$x = 5
$a[$x, $x + 1, $x + 2]
```

# Expected behavior

Addition should be more similar to multiplication, taking place before the comma operator in the absence of explicit parentheses.

```none
5
6
7
```

# Actual behavior

```none
5
5
1
5
2
```

As it is not completely clear, what's actually happening is that PS is treating the resolution more like it was entered like this:

```none
$a[ @($x, $x) + @(1, $x) + 2 ]
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.1.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17134
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

body:
# Support Question
I've been messing around with a project today and noticed that sometimes my requests fail, I couldn't quite nail it down until I installed Fiddler and saw that in the headers my script was requesting `Expect: 100-continue`, after a bit of digging I also noticed once I login to the web page manually it returns a 200, I just added `-Headers` to my script to also Expect 200, but I would like to know why this is? I never set it up to expect anything before now.

<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

This repository is **ONLY** for PowerShell Core 6 issues.

- Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/known-issues-ps6?view=powershell-6).

-->

It appears that when Set-Content sets a Newline at the end of the file, the new line is not also included in the content of -PassThru or in the content of `-OutVariable`.

IMO, the output should be an exact match for the content actually placed in the file, including the appended newline.

# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
$Path = 'c:\temp\testfile.txt'
$Result = "a" | Set-Content -Encoding UTF8 -PassThru -OutVariable SetContent -Path $Path
$FileContent = Get-Content -Raw -Path $Path
describe "Newline Parity" {
    It 'OutVariable should be the same as File Content' {
        $SetContent[0] | Should -BeExactly $FileContent
    }
    It 'PassThru should be the same as FileContent' {
        $Result | Should -BeExactly $FileContent
    }
}
```

# Expected behavior

```none
Describing Newline Parity
  [+] OutVariable should be the same as File Content 49ms
  [+] PassThru should be the same as FileContent 46ms
```

# Actual behavior

```none
  [-] OutVariable should be the same as File Content 378ms
    Expected strings to be the same, but they were different.
    Expected length: 3
    Actual length:   1
    Strings differ at index 1.
    Expected: 'a\r
    '
    But was:  'a'
    ------------^
    3:         $SetContent[0] | Should -BeExactly $FileContent
  [-] PassThru should be the same as FileContent 172ms
    Expected strings to be the same, but they were different.
    Expected length: 3
    Actual length:   1
    Strings differ at index 1.
    Expected: 'a\r
    '
    But was:  'a'
    ------------^
    6:         $Result | Should -BeExactly $FileContent
```

body:
## PR Summary

When using a screen reader or just getting the output of a table with lots of rows, the header is no longer on the screen and the columns may no longer make sense without the context.  This PR adds a `-RepeatHeader` switch to `Format-Table` to enable re-outputting the header after every screen full (minus 1 row).  Expectation is that the user is piping the output to a pager (e.g. less) which uses the bottom row for pager information.  I followed the `AutoSize` parameter as the way to get the parameter from the cmdlet into the deep formatting object where it's needed.

![gifv](https://i.imgur.com/t9WbpnX.gif)

Fix https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/8455

body:
# Summary of the new feature/enhancement

While `Start-Sleep -MilliSeconds` offers fine-grained control over the sleep duration, it would be convenient not to have two switch parameters just to be able to effectively specify _fractional_ seconds.

E.g., instead of:

```powershell
Start-Sleep -MilliSeconds 1400
```

it would be nice to be able to write:

```powershell
Start-Sleep 1.4  # wishful thinking; translate into 1,400 msecs.
```

This is in line with the `sleep` utility on macOS and Linux, which accepts fractional values (e.g., `sleep 1.4`)

Currently, fractional values are _quietly converted to `[int]` values_, which means that _rounding_ is applied, which is not only obscure behavior, but behavior that existing code is unlikely to rely upon.

As an aside: `Start-Sleep` is misnamed and should be called `Invoke-Sleep` - see #3990.

# Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Change the data type of the `-Seconds` parameter from `[int]` to `[double]` and simply cast the internal conversion to milliseconds to `(int)`.

body:
## PR Summary
Fix #8308 

`WriteMemberInfoCollection()` incorrectly nests sibling elements at depth==0
The reason seems to be that `WriteMemberInfoCollection()` calls `WriteEndElement()` at most once, even if `WriteStartElement()` has been called more than once.

This PR moves the `WriteEndElement()` call up immediately after the elements text value has been written.

body:
`using module` _only_ works on modules in $env:PSModulePath, i.e., it is _impossible_ to target already-loaded modules.

This can be frustrating when developing and testing modules that make use of custom types in some shape or form that expect them to be exportable from the module.

# Steps to reproduce

## Create two files

1. A simple module file defining a custom attribute. Save as `TestModule.psm1`

```powershell
class CustomAttribute : Attribute {
    CustomAttribute() {}
}
```

2. A file with script-level attribute and `using module` attached. Save as `BrokenFile.ps1`

```powershell
using module TestModule
[Custom()]
param()

Write-Host "hello!"
```

## Attempt to have PowerShell parse the file

We can use `Get-Command` for this; if the parse fails, the resulting object's `ScriptBlock` property is empty.

```
PS> Import-Module .\TestModule.psm1
PS> $Command = Get-Command .\BrokenFile.ps1
PS> $Command.ScriptBlock
```

# Expected behavior

The scriptblock property should be populated, and output the contents to console, as the `using module`  directive is targeting a named module already loaded in the current session.

```none
PS> $Command.ScriptBlock
using module TestModule
[Custom()]
param()

Write-Host "hello!"
```

# Actual behavior

```none
PS> $Command.ScriptBlock
<no output>
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.1.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17763
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

/cc @rjmholt

body:
## PR Summary

Update project and NuGet packages to `netcoreapp2.1` and `6.1.1` NuGet packages, old projects before 6.0 RTM time are being removed.
I checked it works by running `dotnet run` on the project.
cc @rkeithhill 

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
    - Use the present tense and imperative mood when describing your changes
- [x] [Summarized changes](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
- [x] [Change is not breaking](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#making-breaking-changes)
- [x] [Make sure all `.h`, `.cpp`, `.cs`, `.ps1` and `.psm1` files have the correct copyright header](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
- [x] This PR is ready to merge and is not [Work in Progress](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---work-in-progress).
    - If the PR is work in progress, please add the prefix `WIP:` to the beginning of the title and remove the prefix when the PR is ready.
- **User-facing changes**
    - [ ] Not Applicable
    - **OR**
    - [ ] User-facing [Documentation needed](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
        - [ ] Issue filed - Issue link:
- **Testing - New and feature**
    - [ ] Not Applicable or can only be tested interactively
    - **OR**
    - [ ] [Make sure you've added a new test if existing tests do not effectively test the code changed](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#before-submitting)
        - [ ] [Add `[feature]` if the change is significant or affects feature tests](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/testing-guidelines/testing-guidelines.md#requesting-additional-tests-for-a-pr)

title: Update the README

body:
Per PowerShell documentation, Enable-PSRemoting and Disable-PSRemoting cmdlets enable and disable *all* remoting endpoints on the local machine.  But PSCore6 versions of these cmdlets affect only PSCore6 endpoints.  The problem with this is that users expect Disable-PSRemoting cmdlet to isolate the local machine from any WinRM/PowerShell connections, but this is no longer true when all Windows PowerShell endpoints remain enabled.

I feel these enable/disable cmdlets should affect all WinRM endpoints on the local machine.  The cmdlet behavior should only differ by what default endpoints they create.  

Enable-PSSessionConfiguration/Disable-PSSessionConfiguration cmdlets can be used to enable/disable individual endpoints.

# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
# Create/register default PSCore6 remote endpoints
Enable-PSRemoting -Force

# Disable endpoints
Disable-PSRemoting -Force

# From Windows PowerShell check its remote endpoints
powershell.exe -c 'Get-PSSessionConfiguration'
```

# Expected behavior

```none
All PowerShell endpoints on local machine are disabled.
```

# Actual behavior

```none
Only PSCore6 endpoints on local machine are disabled.  Windows PowerShell endpoints remain enabled and so PSRemoting remains enabled.
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.2.0-preview.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.2.0-preview.2-68-gc9fc4ef4ec1256ac7082f55c45d4e400cc642767
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17763
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
